thread.title: Arlington denies Nelson, Woburn
thread.title_full: Arlington denies Nelson, Woburn | Boston Herald

author: Sean Brennan
title: Arlington denies Nelson, Woburn
text:
The celebration in Woburn has been put on hold. The celebration in Arlington may last all weekend.
Trailing 33-21 with just over four minutes remaining last night in Arlington, the host Spy Ponders pulled off a miracle comeback behind an all-worldly performance from senior quarterback Alec Coleman (four rushing touchdowns), a timely onside kick and some last-minute magic to take a thrilling 34-33 victory over the Tanners on a night when Woburn coach Rocky Nelson looked set to record his 200th career win.
“We talked to the guys about never giving up and believing in themselves,” said Arlington coach Ryan Gendron. “We kept believing in our guys and they pulled it off. That was a great high school football game. It came down to us having the ball last and we made the plays.”
After Woburn’s Doug Amaral scored his third TD from 11 yards out to put the Tanners up by 12, Coleman stole the show. His 9-yard touchdown capped off a 10-play, 67-yard drive, which cut the deficit to 33-28 with 1:39 left.
And after the Spy Ponders executed a perfect onside kick, Coleman did it again. His 4-yard TD plunge, which came after a pass interference call in the end zone, ended up being the final nail in the coffin on a night when Arlington (4-1) also rallied from a 20-0 hole in the first half.
Early, it looked as if Woburn (2-3) would hand Nelson his milestone win with ease. A Dan Moscat 40-yard run out of the punt formation gave the Tanners the early first quarter lead, and after Amaral rumbled in from 13 yards out later in the quarter, momentum was on Woburn’s side.
But after falling behind 20-0 early in the second on a 20-yard TD run from Moscat, Coleman scored on a 1-yard sneak before a 9-yard scoring toss to Clark Ewen made it 20-14 at the break. And following Amaral’s third score of the night early in the fourth, Coleman went 67 yards to make it 27-21, setting up the dramatic finish.
In other action last night:
Marco King threw a pair of TD passes as BC High (4-1) held off Malden Catholic , 17-14, in the Catholic Conference.
Luis Cardona scored two touchdowns, including a 63-yard punt return, to lead Everett (2-3) to a 49-20 win over Medford in Greater Boston League play.
Perry Winn scored two rushing touchdowns as Andover (4-1) earned a 44-20 win over Lowell in Merrimack Valley Conference Large action.
Christian Friedel ran for two TDs and Jack Masterson threw for two more as No. 3 Marshfield (5-0) took a 50-7 win over Falmouth in the Atlantic Coast League.
Sam Foley threw a pair of touchdown passes as Needham (3-2) beat Weymouth , 21-10, in a Bay State Carey tilt.
Malik Williams put Natick (2-3) ahead for good with a 6-yard touchdown run early in the fourth quarter as the Redhawks defeated Dedham , 16-6, in the Bay State Herget.
Julian Nyland ran for a 60-yard touchdown and threw a 53-yard touchdown pass as Melrose (5-0) shut out Wilmington , 34-0, in the Middlesex Freedom. . . . Dylan Bonfilio scored twice, including a 19-yarder in the fourth quarter, to give Burlington (3-2) a 21-17 win over Watertown .
Tim Warren threw four touchdown passes to lead Medfield (3-2) to a 28-7 victory over Medway in the Tri-Valley Large. . . . Jack Barrett threw for two scores and ran for two more as Holliston (5-0) handled Hopkinton , 35-14.
Ethan McCollough carried the ball 24 times for 163 yards and three touchdowns to give Lincoln-Sudbury (1-4) a 43-8 victory over Cambridge in the Dual County Large. . . . Connor Degenhardt ran for two touchdowns as Westford Academy (4-0) scored 21 unanswered points to come back and defeat Waltham , 21-10.
John DeLuca scored the only touchdown of the game as King Philip (2-3) defeated Franklin , 10-3, in the Hockomock Kelley-Rex. . . . North Attleboro (5-0) scored twice in the first quarter, including a 64-yard interception return by Patrick Johnson, in a 14-0 win over Attleboro .
In the Hockomock Davenport, Jake Ragusa finished with two rushing touchdowns and Canton (4-1) stopped a game-winning two-point try by Stoughton in overtime to preserve a 22-21 victory. . . . Robbie Bayha threw two TD passes as Sharon (2-3) defeated Oliver Ames , 28-12.
Jake Eliason rushed for 153 yards and three scores on 27 carries as Bedford (3-2) defeated Weston, 28-14, in Dual County Small play. . . . Andrew Jemelli scored three times for Concord-Carlisle (4-1) in a 56-28 victory over Boston Latin .
Abraham Toe busted loose for St. Mary’s (4-1), with four scoring runs in a 32-8 victory over Archbishop Williams in the Catholic Central Large. . . . Cory Bright (194 yards passing, four TDs) threw a game-winning 20-yard TD pass to Cody Mullen (10 catches, 137 yards, three TDs) on the final play to give Bishop Fenwick (5-0) a 26-21 win over Austin Prep .
Ivan Mertilus had 252 rushing yards and three TDs, leading the way for St. Clement (3-2) in a 46-0 victory over Matignon/St. Joseph’s , in the Catholic Central Small.
In a Boston North matchup, Terrance Moore and Nathan Rivera combined for 213 yards and four scores on nine carries as East Boston (4-1) blanked West Roxbury , 40-0. . . . Anthony Cannady scored four touchdowns as Madison Park (5-0) remained undefeated, beating Charlestown , 46-6.
John Teehan ran for two TDs and passed for a third as Latin Academy (2-3) beat Burke , 34-6, in Boston City South.
In a nonleague contest, Jared Martino tossed four touchdowns and Danley Exilhomme rushed for 145 yards as Malden (3-2) edged Chelmsford , 42-36, in double overtime.
David Pollard, Robyn Hayes, Kat Hasenauer Cornetta, Matt Feld and Kevin Barrucci contributed to this report.
